title: Position of zero net electric field of 2 charges

content.description: Two small spheres are positioned a distance of <math alttext="4 centimeters" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>4</mn><mtext> cm</mtext></math> from each other on the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis as shown above. Sphere <math alttext="A" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>A</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a charge of <math alttext="positive 3 microcoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>+</mo><mn>3.0</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>μC</mtext></math>, while sphere <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>B</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> has a charge of <math alttext="negative 2 microcoulombs" overflow="scroll" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mo>−</mo><mn>2.0</mn><mo> </mo><mtext>μC</mtext></math>.
content.question: What is the <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-coordinate of the point at which the net electric field due to the spheres is zero?
